name: PDS 70
scenarioDescription:
The PDS 70 Exoplanetary System


Overview

PDS 70 is a star with 0.76 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.26 times its radius. It is located 369.9587508 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 0.005 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

PDS 70 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the PDS 70 system

PDS 70 b

PDS 70 b was discovered by the Paranal Observatory observatory using the Imaging method. The mass of PDS 70 b is 2542.64 times the mass of Earth. The radius of PDS 70 b is 14.572 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, PDS 70 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system. At more than 50 Earth masses, PDS 70 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


PDS 70 c

PDS 70 c was discovered by the European Southern Observatory observatory using the Imaging method.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system PDS 70, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Paranal Observatory.
